title: Heathrow Airport Implements New Security Scanners to Ease Travel Restrictions
summary: Heathrow Airport has completed the rollout of new CT scanners across all terminals, making it the world's largest airport with this technology fully implemented. This upgrade allows passengers to keep liquids in containers up to two liters in their luggage during security checks, eliminating the need for clear plastic bags and the removal of electronics like laptops. The change aims to enhance efficiency by processing thousands of passengers per hour while maintaining safety standards. However, it only applies to flights departing from Heathrow, so travelers must verify restrictions at other airports, especially when returning to the UK. Other UK airports, such as Gatwick, Edinburgh, and Birmingham, have also adopted similar scanners and raised liquid limits, but some are awaiting approval from the Department for Transport to increase from 100ml. Despite benefits, a report by Which? indicates that the scanners' sensitivity may lead to more manual bag searches. The rollout faced delays, including pandemic impacts and missed deadlines, with smaller airports meeting the June 2024 target while larger ones like Heathrow lagged. Overall, this represents a significant shift in airport security rules, promising faster and more convenient travel.

background_read: Airport security has evolved significantly since the early 2000s, with strict liquid limits introduced after terror threats. The 100ml rule, requiring liquids in clear plastic bags, became standard globally to enhance safety. In recent years, advancements in CT scanning technology have allowed for more detailed baggage inspection, prompting airports to reconsider these restrictions. The UK government, under Boris Johnson, pledged to remove the 100ml limit by 2022, but delays occurred due to the COVID-19 pandemic. A subsequent deadline of June 2024 was set for installing state-of-the-art scanners, with smaller airports meeting it while larger ones like Heathrow faced challenges. This shift aims to balance security with passenger convenience, reflecting broader trends in travel innovation.
